     204             : 
     205             :   // PopulateConsoleNotificationInTheTargetScope receives aCx and aArguments in
     206             :   // the same JS compartment and populates the ConsoleEvent object (aValue) in
     207             :   // the aTargetScope.
     208             :   // aTargetScope can be:
     209             :   // - the system-principal scope when we want to dispatch the ConsoleEvent to
     210             :   //   nsIConsoleAPIStorage (See the comment in Console.cpp about the use of
     211             :   //   xpc::PrivilegedJunkScope()
     212             :   // - the mConsoleEventNotifier->Callable() scope when we want to notify this
     213             :   //   handler about a new ConsoleEvent.
     214             :   // - It can be the global from the JSContext when RetrieveConsoleEvents is
     215             :   //   called.
     216             :   bool
     217             :   PopulateConsoleNotificationInTheTargetScope(JSContext* aCx,
     218             :                                               const Sequence<JS::Value>& aArguments,
     219             :                                               JSObject* aTargetScope,
     220             :                                               JS::MutableHandle<JS::Value> aValue,
     221             :                                               ConsoleCallData* aData) const;
     222             : 
     223             :   // If the first JS::Value of the array is a string, this method uses it to
     224             :   // format a string. The supported sequences are:
     225             :   //   %s    - string
     226             :   //   %d,%i - integer
     227             :   //   %f    - double
     228             :   //   %o,%O - a JS object.
     229             :   //   %c    - style string.
     230             :   // The output is an array where any object is a separated item, the rest is
     231             :   // unified in a format string.
     232             :   // Example if the input is:
     233             :   //   "string: %s, integer: %d, object: %o, double: %d", 's', 1, window, 0.9
     234             :   // The output will be:
     235             :   //   [ "string: s, integer: 1, object: ", window, ", double: 0.9" ]
     236             :   //
     237             :   // The aStyles array is populated with the style strings that the function
     238             :   // finds based the format string. The index of the styles matches the indexes
     239             :   // of elements that need the custom styling from aSequence. For elements with
     240             :   // no custom styling the array is padded with null elements.
     241             :   bool
     242             :   ProcessArguments(JSContext* aCx, const Sequence<JS::Value>& aData,
     243             :                    Sequence<JS::Value>& aSequence,
     244             :                    Sequence<nsString>& aStyles) const;
     245             : 
     246             :   void
     247             :   MakeFormatString(nsCString& aFormat, int32_t aInteger, int32_t aMantissa,
     248             :                    char aCh) const;
     249             : 
     250             :   // Stringify and Concat all the JS::Value in a single string using ' ' as
     251             :   // separator.
     252             :   void
     253             :   ComposeGroupName(JSContext* aCx, const Sequence<JS::Value>& aData,
     254             :                    nsAString& aName) const;
     255             : 
     256             :   // StartTimer is called on the owning thread and populates aTimerLabel and
     257             :   // aTimerValue. It returns false if a JS exception is thrown or if
     258             :   // the max number of timers is reached.
     259             :   // * aCx - the JSContext rooting aName.
     260             :   // * aName - this is (should be) the name of the timer as JS::Value.
     261             :   // * aTimestamp - the monotonicTimer for this context taken from
     262             :   //                performance.now().
     263             :   // * aTimerLabel - This label will be populated with the aName converted to a
     264             :   //                 string.
     265             :   // * aTimerValue - the StartTimer value stored into (or taken from)
     266             :   //                 mTimerRegistry.
     267             :   bool
     268             :   StartTimer(JSContext* aCx, const JS::Value& aName,
     269             :              DOMHighResTimeStamp aTimestamp,
     270             :              nsAString& aTimerLabel,
     271             :              DOMHighResTimeStamp* aTimerValue);
     272             : 
     273             :   // CreateStartTimerValue generates a ConsoleTimerStart dictionary exposed as
     274             :   // JS::Value. If aTimerStatus is false, it generates a ConsoleTimerError
     275             :   // instead. It's called only after the execution StartTimer on the owning
     276             :   // thread.
     277             :   // * aCx - this is the context that will root the returned value.
     278             :   // * aTimerLabel - this label must be what StartTimer received as aTimerLabel.
     279             :   // * aTimerStatus - the return value of StartTimer.
     280             :   JS::Value
     281             :   CreateStartTimerValue(JSContext* aCx, const nsAString& aTimerLabel,
     282             :                         bool aTimerStatus) const;
     283             : 
     284             :   // StopTimer follows the same pattern as StartTimer: it runs on the
     285             :   // owning thread and populates aTimerLabel and aTimerDuration, used by
     286             :   // CreateStopTimerValue. It returns false if a JS exception is thrown or if
     287             :   // the aName timer doesn't exist in the mTimerRegistry.
     288             :   // * aCx - the JSContext rooting aName.
     289             :   // * aName - this is (should be) the name of the timer as JS::Value.
     290             :   // * aTimestamp - the monotonicTimer for this context taken from
     291             :   //                performance.now().
     292             :   // * aTimerLabel - This label will be populated with the aName converted to a
     293             :   //                 string.
     294             :   // * aTimerDuration - the difference between aTimestamp and when the timer
     295             :   //                    started (see StartTimer).
     296             :   bool
     297             :   StopTimer(JSContext* aCx, const JS::Value& aName,
     298             :             DOMHighResTimeStamp aTimestamp,
     299             :             nsAString& aTimerLabel,
     300             :             double* aTimerDuration);
     301             : 
     302             :   // This method generates a ConsoleTimerEnd dictionary exposed as JS::Value, or
     303             :   // a ConsoleTimerError dictionary if aTimerStatus is false. See StopTimer.
     304             :   // * aCx - this is the context that will root the returned value.
     305             :   // * aTimerLabel - this label must be what StopTimer received as aTimerLabel.
     306             :   // * aTimerDuration - this is what StopTimer received as aTimerDuration
     307             :   // * aTimerStatus - the return value of StopTimer.
     308             :   JS::Value
     309             :   CreateStopTimerValue(JSContext* aCx, const nsAString& aTimerLabel,
     310             :                        double aTimerDuration,
     311             :                        bool aTimerStatus) const;
     312             : 
     313             :   // The method populates a Sequence from an array of JS::Value.
     314             :   bool
     315             :   ArgumentsToValueList(const Sequence<JS::Value>& aData,
     316             :                        Sequence<JS::Value>& aSequence) const;
     317             : 
     318             :   // This method follows the same pattern as StartTimer: its runs on the owning
     319             :   // thread and populate aCountLabel, used by CreateCounterValue. Returns
     320             :   // MAX_PAGE_COUNTERS in case of error, otherwise the incremented counter
     321             :   // value.
     322             :   // * aCx - the JSContext rooting aData.
     323             :   // * aFrame - the first frame of ConsoleCallData.

     330             : 
     331             :   // This method generates a ConsoleCounter dictionary as JS::Value. If
     332             :   // aCountValue is == MAX_PAGE_COUNTERS it generates a ConsoleCounterError
     333             :   // instead. See IncreaseCounter.
     334             :   // * aCx - this is the context that will root the returned value.

     363             :   nsTArray<RefPtr<ConsoleCallData>> mCallDataStorage;
     364             : 
     365             :   // This array is used in a particular corner-case where:
     366             :   // 1. we are in a worker thread
     367             :   // 2. we have more than STORAGE_MAX_EVENTS
     368             :   // 3. but the main-thread ConsoleCallDataRunnable of the first one is still
     369             :   // running (this means that something very bad is happening on the
     370             :   // main-thread).
     371             :   // When this happens we want to keep the ConsoleCallData alive for traceing
     372             :   // its JSValues also if 'officially' this ConsoleCallData must be removed from
     373             :   // the storage.
     374             :   nsTArray<RefPtr<ConsoleCallData>> mCallDataStoragePending;
